korean_style_beef_bulgogi_1758913342.title: Korean-Style Beef Bulgogi

all_ingredients.name: Salt and black pepper, to taste
Cooked white or brown rice, for serving

instructions: In a large bowl, whisk together Gochujang, soy sauce, brown sugar, garlic, ginger, and chili flakes.
Add the sliced beef to the marinade and toss to coat. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Preheat a grill or grill pan to medium-high heat. Remove the beef from the marinade, letting any excess liquid drip off.
Grill the beef for 3-4 minutes per side, or until cooked to your desired level of doneness. Transfer the beef to a plate and let it rest for a few minutes.
In a small bowl, whisk together rice vinegar and sesame oil.
Slice the grilled beef against the grain into thin strips. Serve with steamed white or brown rice, drizzled with the sesame-ginger sauce (step 5).

health_notes: beef:** rich in protein, vitamins b12 and niacin, and minerals like iron and zinc. grass-fed beef may contain more omega-3 fatty acids.
sesame oil:** rich in healthy fats (monounsaturated and polyunsaturated) and antioxidants. may help lower cholesterol and improve heart health.
green onions:** good source of vitamin k, folate, and fiber. may help support digestive health.

tips: For an extra crispy glaze, brush the beef with a mixture of equal parts soy sauce, honey, and rice vinegar during the last minute of grilling.
Substitute beef with thinly sliced pork or chicken for a different twist on Bulgogi.
Add some crunch by sprinkling toasted sesame seeds and chopped green onions over the top of the dish before serving.
Serve with kimchi (spicy Korean fermented cabbage) for an added kick.
Always handle raw meat safely to avoid cross-contamination. Wash your hands thoroughly after handling the beef and any utensils or cutting boards used in preparation.
Cook the beef to a safe internal temperature of 145°F (63°C) for medium-rare, 160°F (71°C) for medium, and 170°F (77°C) for well-done.
Enjoy your delicious Korean-Style Beef Bulgogi!
korean_style_beef_bulgogi_1758913342.raw_text:
**Korean-Style Beef Bulgogi**

Serving size: 4-6 servings

**Ingredients:**

* 1 pound beef (such as ribeye or sirloin), sliced into thin strips
* 2 tablespoons Gochujang (Korean chili paste)
* 2 tablespoons soy sauce
* 2 tablespoons brown sugar
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger
* 1/4 cup Korean chili flakes (gochugaru)
* 1/4 cup rice vinegar
* 1/4 cup sesame oil
* 1/4 cup chopped green onions for garnish
* 1/4 cup toasted sesame seeds for garnish
* Salt and black pepper, to taste
* Cooked white or brown rice, for serving

**Instructions:**

1. In a large bowl, whisk together Gochujang, soy sauce, brown sugar, garlic, ginger, and chili flakes.
2. Add the sliced beef to the marinade and toss to coat. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight.
3. Preheat a grill or grill pan to medium-high heat. Remove the beef from the marinade, letting any excess liquid drip off.
4. Grill the beef for 3-4 minutes per side, or until cooked to your desired level of doneness. Transfer the beef to a plate and let it rest for a few minutes.
5. In a small bowl, whisk together rice vinegar and sesame oil.
6. Slice the grilled beef against the grain into thin strips. Serve with steamed white or brown rice, drizzled with the sesame-ginger sauce (step 5).

**Tips and Variations:**

* For an extra crispy glaze, brush the beef with a mixture of equal parts soy sauce, honey, and rice vinegar during the last minute of grilling.
* Substitute beef with thinly sliced pork or chicken for a different twist on Bulgogi.
* Add some crunch by sprinkling toasted sesame seeds and chopped green onions over the top of the dish before serving.
* Serve with kimchi (spicy Korean fermented cabbage) for an added kick.

**Food Safety Notes:**

* Always handle raw meat safely to avoid cross-contamination. Wash your hands thoroughly after handling the beef and any utensils or cutting boards used in preparation.
* Cook the beef to a safe internal temperature of 145°F (63°C) for medium-rare, 160°F (71°C) for medium, and 170°F (77°C) for well-done.

Enjoy your delicious Korean-Style Beef Bulgogi!

lamb_s_golden_hour_stew_1758913687.title: Lamb's Golden Hour Stew

all_ingredients.name: boneless lamb shoulder or neck, cut into 2-inch pieces

instructions: In a large Dutch oven or heavy pot, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add the lamb pieces and cook until browned on all sides, about 5-7 minutes. Remove the lamb from the pot and set it aside.
Reduce the heat to medium and add the chopped onion to the pot. Cook until the onion is translucent and starting to caramelize, stirring occasionally, about 10-12 minutes.
Add the minced garlic and cook for an additional minute, stirring constantly to prevent burning.
Add the chopped carrots and celery to the pot. Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they start to soften.
Add the diced tomatoes, lamb broth or beef broth, dried oregano, salt, and pepper to the pot. Stir to combine.
Return the browned lamb to the pot and bring the stew to a simmer.
Cover the pot with a lid and transfer it to the preheated oven.
Braise the stew for 2-3 hours or until the lamb is tender and falls apart easily. Check on the stew every hour, adding more liquid if necessary, and stirring occasionally.
Remove the pot from the oven and let it cool slightly before serving.

health_notes: lamb:** rich in protein, vitamins b12 and e, and minerals like zinc, iron, and phosphorus. lamb also contains conjugated linoleic acid (cla), which may help with weight management and immune function.
celery:** rich in vitamins k and c, potassium, and fiber, celery promotes healthy blood clotting, cardiovascular health, and digestive regularity.

tips: For added depth of flavor, add a few sprigs of fresh thyme or rosemary to the pot during the last 30 minutes of braising.
Serve the stew with crusty bread, over mashed potatoes, or with a side of roasted vegetables for a hearty meal.
To make ahead, prepare the stew up to step 9, then refrigerate or freeze it. Reheat and serve.
Always handle raw meat safely by washing your hands before and after handling the lamb.
Cook the lamb to an internal temperature of at least 145°F (63°C) for medium-rare, 160°F (71°C) for medium, or 170°F (77°C) for well-done.
Enjoy your delicious and flavorful Lamb's Golden Hour Stew!
lamb_s_golden_hour_stew_1758913687.raw_text:
Lamb's Golden Hour Stew

**Serving size:** 4-6 servings

**Ingredients:**

* 1 pound boneless lamb shoulder or neck, cut into 2-inch pieces
* 2 tablespoons olive oil
* 1 large onion, chopped (about 3 cups)
* 3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 tablespoon)
* 2 medium carrots, peeled and chopped (about 2 cups)
* 2 stalks celery, chopped (about 1 cup)
* 1 can (14.5 oz) diced tomatoes
* 1 cup lamb broth or beef broth
* 1 teaspoon dried oregano
* Salt and pepper, to taste
* Fresh parsley, chopped (optional)

**Instructions:**

1. Preheat the oven to 325°F (165°C).
2. In a large Dutch oven or heavy pot, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat.
3. Add the lamb pieces and cook until browned on all sides, about 5-7 minutes. Remove the lamb from the pot and set it aside.
4. Reduce the heat to medium and add the chopped onion to the pot. Cook until the onion is translucent and starting to caramelize, stirring occasionally, about 10-12 minutes.
5. Add the minced garlic and cook for an additional minute, stirring constantly to prevent burning.
6. Add the chopped carrots and celery to the pot. Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they start to soften.
7. Add the diced tomatoes, lamb broth or beef broth, dried oregano, salt, and pepper to the pot. Stir to combine.
8. Return the browned lamb to the pot and bring the stew to a simmer.
9. Cover the pot with a lid and transfer it to the preheated oven.
10. Braise the stew for 2-3 hours or until the lamb is tender and falls apart easily. Check on the stew every hour, adding more liquid if necessary, and stirring occasionally.
11. Remove the pot from the oven and let it cool slightly before serving.

**Optional Tips:**

* For added depth of flavor, add a few sprigs of fresh thyme or rosemary to the pot during the last 30 minutes of braising.
* Serve the stew with crusty bread, over mashed potatoes, or with a side of roasted vegetables for a hearty meal.
* To make ahead, prepare the stew up to step 9, then refrigerate or freeze it. Reheat and serve.

**Food Safety Notes:**

* Always handle raw meat safely by washing your hands before and after handling the lamb.
* Cook the lamb to an internal temperature of at least 145°F (63°C) for medium-rare, 160°F (71°C) for medium, or 170°F (77°C) for well-done.

Enjoy your delicious and flavorful Lamb's Golden Hour Stew!
